title: How to Write Science Fiction and Fantasy - Introduction and Philosophy
summary: Brandon Sanderson's introductory lecture to his Science Fiction and Fantasy writing class at BYU covers his teaching philosophy, the importance of developing a personal writing process, and the realities of pursuing a professional writing career. He emphasizes the need to treat writing as a craft to be mastered, the validity of different writing styles (outlining vs. discovery writing), and the importance of understanding survivorship bias when seeking advice. He also stresses the value of writing, regardless of professional aspirations, and offers guidance on writing groups and revision.

concepts.name: Writing Process
concepts.description: The individual approach and methods a writer uses to create their work, including outlining, discovery writing, revision, and habit formation. Sanderson emphasizes the importance of finding what works best for each writer through experimentation and self-awareness.

concepts.name: Professional vs. Non-Professional Writing
concepts.description: The distinction between writing as a hobby or personal enrichment versus pursuing it as a full-time career. Sanderson acknowledges the validity of both paths but focuses the class on providing tools for those aspiring to be professional science fiction and fantasy writers.

concepts.name: Chef vs. Cook
concepts.description: A metaphor for the difference between blindly following writing rules and understanding the underlying principles to adapt and create effectively. Sanderson encourages students to become 'chefs' who can understand and manipulate the elements of writing.

concepts.name: Survivorship Bias
concepts.description: The tendency to overvalue the advice of successful individuals without considering that their success may be due to luck or factors not applicable to everyone. Sanderson cautions against blindly following advice without critical evaluation.

concepts.name: Artistic Integrity vs. Business Acumen
concepts.description: The balance between maintaining artistic vision and making pragmatic decisions to market and sell one's work. Sanderson suggests separating the artistic and business mindsets to avoid compromising the creative process.

concepts.name: Revision
concepts.description: The process of reviewing, editing, and improving a written work. Sanderson emphasizes its importance as a skill to be learned and practiced, and offers advice on how to approach it effectively.

notes.heading: Introduction to the Class
bullets: The class is a lecture series on science fiction and fantasy writing at Brigham Young University.
The course will cover introductory material, Sanderson's teaching philosophy, and the difference between discovery writers and outline writers.
The class approaches writing with the goal of becoming a professional writer.
The goal of the class is to receive a firehose of information about writing, that can also be found later on Youtube.

notes.heading: Philosophy of Teaching Writing
bullets: Writing is hard to teach because you learn more by writing than can be taught.
Writing requires work, effort, exploration, and revision.
Writing advice is only as good as its ability to help you individually; bad advice for you is possible.
Most writers are a mix of 'gardener' (discovery writer) and 'architect' (outliner).
Treat students as 'chefs' who understand the principles of writing, not just 'cooks' who follow recipes.

notes.heading: Being a Professional vs. Non-Professional Writer
bullets: It is perfectly fine to be a nonprofessional writer; writing is good for personal enrichment.
People often ask writers if they are published or when they will make money from their books.
Society treats art too utilitarianly, overlooking the primary purpose of enriching the artist's life.
The class will primarily focus on advice for those wanting to make a full-time living as a science fiction/fantasy novelist.
Advice for aspiring professionals encompasses advice for other writing goals.

notes.heading: Making a Living as a Novelist (Realistically)
bullets: Making a living as a professional novelist is difficult, like being a professional musician or fine artist.
Writing fiction and making a living at it is hard, but not as hard as it used to be.
If seriously dedicated, you have a better than one in twenty shot of making a significant portion of your income from writing if you work hard for 10 years.
Even among those who go pro, only a few regularly hit the New York Times bestseller list.
Your job as a writer early on is to write enough books to learn your process, not to sell books.
It's generally advised to finish several novels before seriously pursuing publication to develop style and consistency.
Approach your writing like learning the piano; early books are like learning scales.

notes.heading: Philosophy on Artistic Expression
bullets: While writing a book, the artist should be in control and make the best decisions for the story and characters.
After finishing the book, a 'business person' should take over to exploit the book for profit.
Do not compromise artistic integrity through revisions solely for business reasons.
There should be communication between business and artistic aspects of the work.

notes.heading: Revision Advice
bullets: Revision is a difficult but essential skill to learn.
There's an argument for putting aside the first book and coming back later.
Discovery writers tend to over-revise early chapters and never finish the book.
Those writers who constantly revise the early chapters, they don't tend to make it.

notes.heading: Motivation to Write
bullets: The thought of having to get a job that Sanderson didn't enjoy made him write.
Hours passed when writing and Sanderson wouldn't know what time it was.
Sanderson kept a spreadsheet of the amount he wrote each day.
Sanderson felt like he was working his way up a progress bar in an MMO.

notes.heading: Survivorship Bias
bullets: Our brains are more likely to weigh the words of someone who's been successful, even if their success was random, than someone who has not been.

notes.heading: Almost Giving Up
bullets: Sanderson applied to grad schools and got rejected from all of them.
Sanderson had written around 12 novels and hadn't sold any.
Sanderson got into BYU's grad program, but it didn't have an MFA.
Sanderson decided that he would write for the rest of his life before he became one of the most famous writers in the world.

notes.heading: Questions and Answers
bullets: Writing all books in the same world is okay.
Ideas are cheap.
It is more important to be a good writer, than to have a good idea.
Find what triggers yourself to write.

notes.heading: Writing Groups
bullets: If you are a discovery writer, be very careful about taking any advice for your book until after you have finished said book and are working on a different one.
If you are getting feedback, try not to say anything.
If you are giving feedback, be descriptive, not proscriptive.

key_facts.fact: The class is a lecture series on science fiction and fantasy writing at Brigham Young University.
The core ideas covered include plot, setting, character, and the business of writing.
Sanderson estimates that about one in 20 dedicated writers will make a significant portion of their income from writing within 10 years.
Sanderson sold his sixth book (Elantris), while Dan Wells sold his sixth, illustrating the importance of practice.
Harry Potter, Twilight, and Name of the Wind were all first books.
